commentBody:
Buried in this story is "Like Mr. Hegseth, Mr. Kerik repeatedly appeared on Fox News pleading Chief Gallagher’s case.'"

Recall that Guilliani elevated Kerik from being his driver to be the Police Commissioner of NYC.  A job that Kerik was not qualified to even apply for based on the regs. which Guillani changed to make it happen.   In 2010, Kerik was sentenced to four years in prison after pleading guilty to eight felony charges, including tax fraud and lying to White House officials. There were other charges and a fine as well. 

What did Giuliani know and when did he know it    Giuliani has somehow avoided prosecution so far.

America , you STINK !
I wonder how public opinion would shift if the infamous photo was released to the public.
the UCMJ is fair. No soldier should be allowed to show pictures of torture. taking the pin is the right.

Psychopath killer Gallagher and his admirer Trump are a perfect pair and typical product of “the country with most arms percapita. 

Americans have a history of violence and global military activity and live in a culture of violence, where weapons are a symbol of power and questionable mental health issues.

Toxic cocktail,  a society that value and glamorise violence,  children and youth are routinely exposed to  in television, social media, and video games. When a child becomes an adult, will have seen 16,000 assassinations and 200,000 acts of violence on television. That’s how our children are numbed to all the violence and accept it as a means to solve problems. They imitate what they see on television and identifying with the victims or the victimised.

A typical Gallagher is a most common profile, reclusive, with relationship problems with others and without a family’s support. When someone with a personality disorder and a mental condition is in search of answers because this alienated person feels that he deserves something better and has access to a firearm, the risk of finding "power" with violence is present. This is not only a mental health issue but a social and political problem too.

Sadly what Chicago Tribune truly said Trump “ is doing damage to the culture of civility and tolerance in America by promoting nastiness as his personal political brand. And he’s failing in the traditional presidential role of providing moral leadership to the country”.

The Seals found Edward Gallagher guilty and convicted him of his crimes. They expelled him from their organization for violating the code of conduct and ethics he took an oath to uphold.  The Seals regard Gallagher as someone who has disgraced himself while wearing the trident symbol.  What basis does Trump have for saying this traitor was treated unfairly?
The Constitution has been attacked.  The law of our country is now similar to the period before Sinai when the golden calf was made. Paganism thrives.

Take away his Trident and get him the help he needs to integrate back into the civilian world.
Whether he's stable or not, he's obviously compromised from a military standpoint and no one (least of all a Navy Seal in good standing) should be required to follow orders from him.

While this appears to be a well researched article, the NY Times pulled its punches. Gallagher's actions, had they been committed by the the knifing victim, would undoubtedly have been labeled "terrorism". Yet, the NT Times didn't describe Gallagher's actions as such.
Of course, from an ethical point of view, innocent people do not deserve to be shot, as Gallagher is reported to have done; we also must confront the inconvenient truth that high U.S. military generals knew that their military plans included killing innocents. But now, Pres. Trump is using his position as commander in chief to shield terrorists.
Unfortunately, I suspect we will be hearing more about Gallagher in the future. His enjoyment of violence (and killing) won't be so easily quenched in civilian society.

commentBody:
Trump's intervention in this case should result in:

Chief Gallagher forfeiting his Trident at the direction of a future president.

Trump's removal from office for yet another instance of degrading our national security.

Congress banning foreign ownership of U.S. media, such as Murdoch-owned Fox.

I believe the larger lesson here,is trump's belief and absolute willingness, to overrule proper military authority,in ALL circumstances.Such a generic assertion may not be validated by trump's single act,but it certainly poses the probability.
    In an 'international incident,scenario,what military advice would trump follow,if Any?In a possible incident with Russia,resulting in the death(s) of American personnel,what would be trump's reaction?Aggression or more likely,passivity?While we all dread such conundrums,they must be considered.The very idea of ultimate singular command by a president whose very neurological fitness we question,seems a bad gamble at best.Kafka said 'the meaning of life,is that it Stops.No American wants to 'go before his or her time and certainly not left to one whose judgement we ridicule if not berate.trump has reached the end of his capabilities.An end  that was 'swift.Ultimately Americans must ask themselves,'can we do better?...We Can...period.full stop!

To all those people saying “Trump is the commander-in-chief” and “Trump is the chain of command” - though both of those statements are correct, that doesn’t absolve him of the need to act reasonably and in accordance with long-established norms and practices, nor does that give him license to make ill-informed decisions based on personal whim or personal political expedience. 

It’s impossible to imagine any other president in the history of this country being applauded for publicly stating that he knows more than “his” generals (actually, Donald, they’re “our” generals, not “yours,” because their oath is to the US Constitution, not to you personally), especially considering that those words come from the mouth of a serial draft dodger whose entire life is a history of self-interest, not service to others.

I'm waiting for the day Mr Trump finally announces that he's president for life and there's no constitution, house, senate or even judiciary that may stop him. I'm also ready for the Republican Party to say, "We're OK with that."

The military is no bastion of virtue. They have a long history of soldiers doing terrible things under the protection of a uniform  and cover ups to protect their own. ( it is not surprising  that the doctor in the Gallagher case changed his story). Even though I am not convinced that it is the most judicious approach for the military to always police it's own, there is a process and the process is imperative to maintaining discipline and order. A soldier gone rogue is a dangerous thing: they are highly skilled and armed with weapons of war. The message must be that order must always be maintained or there will be chaos. Perhaps it is this order that helps men and women thrust into daily danger and violence maintain their humanity. Petty Officer Gallagher seems to have lost just that. He is supposed to be fighting to create peace. The minute he sees himself as a killer he poses as a danger to himself and others. Mr. Trump, as the commander in chief, must remind Petty Officer Gallagher of that duty, not condone his murder of an enemy combatant. As grey and confusing as it may be, there must be a difference between death in battle and out right murder. Theoretically the first is part of  military plan; the second is for personal gain. I am not in the military. I would not have done well in that environment. But I have an appreciation for why order and discipline are so vital. Too bad this seems to have eluded the President.

commentBody:
"The medic who had been inches away from Chief Gallagher changed his story on the stand, claiming that he was the one who killed the captive."

Didn't the medic change his story only after he had been granted immunity by the government?

Having served as an officer on Courts Martial and NJP proceedings, in my 20 year active duty experience, they are fair and professionally handled. The good order and discipline that the UCMJ provides has now been severely dented by the Presidents’ misuse of his commander in chief role. Quite simply he has hijacked military leadership principles to pardon rogue “warriors”  turning this into a political firefight. Had he defended his country when called rather than purchasing doctored bone spurs, he may better understand what the military is all about: honor, courage and commitment.

You know, I read articles like this and think to myself this has to end.  it can't continue.  And I go to something else because I think of those who voted for the Grifter-in_chief and assume that they are all right with it.  Sad.  Sad for them and sad for me.

I’m not naive about war. Both my parents were WW2 veterans and my mother’s first husband was killed in the war. I’m sure they were have both found his behavior repulsive and a disgrace to the US military. What I wonder is why was he even on that tour in the first place. According to this attorney he had already been reported for numerous acts and statements, emails etc. that sound like the workings of a psychopath. When he sent that email that “ he just wanted to kill as many people as he could”  (or something very close to that) didn’t that send up a red flag? According to more than one report he’d go on rooftops using a sniper rifle and pick off civilians. He also threatened to kill any Seals who reported his actions. He does not deserve the Trident pin. He really ought to be in jail and not on Fox dissing his commanding officers. And Trump should stay out of this. Just like he should stay out of all the other institutions that he’s trying to destroy.

It was a big mistake for Obama and Holder to back off torture investigations and prosecutions. The US should have loudly condemned torture and sent people to prison. This is the same trajectory, the same moral rot we saw at Abu Ghraib and read about in Guantanamo.  Is this how we want to be known?
No military experience? Trump is a draft dodger. Why play fast and loose with the English language? Just call him what he is, for goodness sakes.

commentBody:
If true, this reminds me of something out of Oliver Stone’s “Platoon,” with Chief Gallagher assuming the role of Sergeant Barnes in that Viet Nam War classic.

But with the headline, “...Pentagon’s Tolerance Is Being Tested,” what’s being implied by the NYT?  A military coup could be imminent, which would be OK because Trump is the Commander in Chief? No!!!
That wouldn’t be OK, even if Gallagher was a certified wacko similar to Sergeant Barnes in Platoon!

What Navy SEAL would trust Gallagher in action?
He’d be too busy whining and moaning
Let Fox and trump  join him in the field 
None of his  comrades will

I must be missing something... Read the first four paragraphs that said "Mr Trump" (who happens to be the President of the United States and "Commander and Chief" of the arm forces overruled the chain of command...  He "is" the Chain of Command!!!  What he says goes... The Joint Chiefs of Staff answer to him as President!!!

He was disrespecting it by jumping in before his ‘turn’—disrespecting those who report to him and their power', 'createDate': '1575257947', 'updateDate': '1575442367', 'approveDate': '1575260817', 'recommendations': 34, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103918702, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'readejl', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103920667', 'isAnonymous': False}]

commentBody:
There is only one question to ask: when first contact with the enemy shoots your battle plan all to hell, is Donald Trump the guy you want on your six, watching your back?

If you can, somehow, answer yes then I can guarantee that:
1.  You’ve never been under fire (and I hope that’s true.) 
2.  Generals McMaster, Mattis and Kelly, to name just a few, would strongly disagree.

Many people in this comment section have talked about a Code of Conduct.  I haven't been able to determine what code of conduct Trump uses, except if Trump thinks it its good for him, then he will do or say it, whether the conduct is moral, legal, or not.

Unfortunately the military hires some bad eggs.  Courts Martial are a part of separating the disgraceful from the honorable.

And Trump, with his supreme insight into the military culture, knows that when there're votes to be had, he'll stoop to no level to get them.

Even at the peril of honorable war fighters, who in the hands of the enemy, may suffer brutal retaliation.

trump with no military experience is not the point. Many presidents had no military experience. The point is that trump just uses these situations for political purposes, to make himself look macho to his supporters, to get votes. He believes in nothing but himself and his own aggrandizement and his image. He can stick his finger in the eye of justice and get away with it. That is what he loves.
Where is the valor or bravery in killing an unanswerable defenseless enemy?

Do the SEALS have a screening mechanism for mental and moral fitness in the face of incredibly stressful and challenging situations that these soliders face?   Gallagher is a straight-up sociopath, exulting in murder and dehumanization.  I wonder what else is in his background may point to these dispositions and if it could have been identified earlier on.   His heinous acts bring dishonor to U.S. forces serving around the world and seeds distrust in our motives and mission abroad.

Trump has in my opinion squandered his political capital long ago, but this episode marks a new low. Shunning the witness to the events that confirmed wrongdoing and booting him out of the military while allowing a war criminal to go free and retire with honor is pathetic. The entire DOD hierarchy should stand true and strong against this callous disregard of duty and honor.

What the subhead calls long-standing rules of combat are actually treaty obligations. The Constitution calls treaties part of the supreme law of the land.

But the Constitution under Donald Trump isn’t worth the parchment it’s written on.

Probably the most unnerving aspect of this entire episode is that Trump is trying to ingratiate himself with the rank and file members of the military in hopes that their loyalty will be more aligned with him than with any other oath they took. These are the circumstances that incubate autocratic dictators.

Being the commander in chief is different from being the owner-proprietor of the US military, just as being the head of the executive branch doesn’t make the Attorney General your personal lawyer. But the distinctions erode every day. Will the day come where the Army will send troops to act as private security at Mar-a-Lago? The possibility seems a lot absurd today than it did 4 years ago.
so he watched the military channel and now he can overturn centuries of military expertise? What an immense ego.

Trump is creating a new ethos in the military where it is not only permissible to be lawless, but it is honored.  Further, he is creating pockets of military personnel who have personal loyalty to him, instead of the chain of command.  Both developments should strike US citizens with grave concern.

Gallagher deserves to lose his pension and face military discipline, including imprisonment for executing a sedated captive. What he did was a war crime, no better than the brutality ISIS fighters wreaked on their captives. He comes across more as someone more interested in legitimatized killing, than in pursuing a honorable career in the SEALS. And Trump is holding him up as a role model. 

Interfering with military discipline to deflect from  his Ukrainian problem, and to once again show his contempt for the rule of any law, from Constitutional to civil and military,  Donald Trump once again proves himself an unqualified, unfit Commander in Chief. His attacks on the Intelligence Community, the FBI and now, the autonomy of the military to police their own should alarm every American.

There is no right or ethical standard at this point. Just a draft dogging bully with the power to excuse someone who is as ethically and legally challenged as he is. Trumps goal is to debase every institution and person to the point where no one could pick him out of a line up of the worse of the most unethical or illegal players. 

There are two America’s now. I cling to the one where truth and character matters. Where the ends don’t justify the means. The other is the party of trump where lying isn’t even considered an issue. The TOP’s (tump Owns Party) have dispensed with any red lines, whether they are deficits, tariffs, legality, truth, corruption, colluding with a foreign government, Turing against allies. They have made  A pack with the Devil, but not to worry they don’t have souls at this point.

All these “pro-military” Trump supporters seem to misunderstand the position of commander-in-chief. Being at the top of the chain of command still means you are part of that chain of command, and like any part of the chain of command the commander-in-chief should respect military discipline and the system of military justice. The US military does not turn into another wholly-owned Trump subsidiary just because he is president.

commentBody:
For several years I worked in mental health with the VA. The Gallagher case may seem extreme but I’ve heard dozens of similar tales from Veterans from WW2 to recent years. Many who served alongside (eventually) speak about it or report it. Most don’t. 

They know they’ll be unsupported by the team if they do. That “accidental” friendly fire and fragging are real. As are thousands of sexual assaults and rape annually of  male and female service members—those too are “investigated” by insiders. 

Most Veterans I knew just tried to get through their 4 years and then quit. Elite units and officer corps are atypical—especially in their willingness to cover up for guys like Gallagher. He’s not as rare as you’d think. 

Ask any therapist who’s worked with Veterans or active duty military. We hear the tortured laments of powerless enlisted ranks who struggled with reporting, and decided the truth would not set them free but more likely get them killed, often decades later. That 6 (of 22 in the platoon, not a high percentage) spoke up about Gallagher is heartening. That others tried to agree on how to play this is much more common.

Trump attracts the very worst elements in the military such as Michael Flynn and Gallagher.   Trump dishonors all Americans and appears to work to destroy this country and its institutions.  All roads lead to Putin.

I just saw a promo for a new war series on cable and oddly, it left me with a feeling of disgust. I didn't pick up on the premise of  whether it's suppose to be funny or serious but after reading about the alleged murderous acts of a "war hero", maybe it's time for the networks give an increasingly war-weary population some rest.

Early in Mr Trump's presidency, he was openly bigoted and derogatory to former military men, and he appeared proud all the while.  

Now he is currying favor from military, or at least he acts as though he believes he is currying favor.   Many of them, with discipline ingrained, believe his behavior is unfavorable.  

I am concerned.  Why would he need the support of the military soon ?    

He is about to be impeached and he neither understands nor obeys, protects, or defends the United States Constitution.  More than one person has spoken of the possibility that he will refuse to leave the White House when it is his time to go.   Aah, then, suddenly, all military are his friends.    I get it.   

"Bone Spurs, begone with thee!   I am actually a good friend of our military.   As I shall soon need them."
Trump’s affinity for Gallagher is completely understandable:  lethal, all-powerful, exultant in triumphant cruelty over a helpless foe, Gallagher is exactly what Trump dreams of being himself.
userLocation: Live in VA. Work in DC.

commentBody: I don’t understand how he thinks he is defending the military or its warriors. What about the other SEALs who spoke out against Gallagher? Are they not warriors? What about Gallagher’s superiors? This seems like a defense of misconduct (putting it lightly; I’m too tired of the blunt truth sounding like hyperbole, as it usually does these days). Not a defense of a warrior.

Tests Pentagons tolerance? I seem to remember from 7th grade civics that the President is the Pentagon's boss. So when the Pentagon reaches the limit of it's tolerance, what are they supposedly going to do?

commentBody:
L'affaire Gallagher indeed raises a more profound disturbing issue. 

As Presidential candidate and after becoming the President Trump daringly exhibited clownish behaviour repeatedly. How on earth did the American people elect such a non intellect as a President? Is this an indication of the average American's intellect?

It indeed speaks about ignorance and denial of reality and inability to live in a changing world, unwilling to make the changes essential to thrive in a new world. Most voters are in denial and unable to see that China is taking over, and prefer to hear lies that make them of being still '#1' rather than acknowledge the need to work, invest in education, science, technology, infrastructure, medicine, world peace etc to remain dominant. 

Instead of looking outwards optimistically of the future, the US is looking inwards!

commentBody: The premise of this story trying to portray the Nuclear armed terror military as gentlemen above Trump is trying my patience. Gallagher IS what the military is, not as you may perceive in the white washed TV and movies. Trump IS the product of a military school in his formative years. You just can't accept the nightmare, can you? Your raising up the military as something above Gallagher's conduct is deeply naive.
Let’s see how one affluent Liberal would stand up after 8 deployments to a war zone - with responsibilities that included killing terrorists.

commentBody: Obviously a stunt for Trump's base. He sees things solely in terms of personal self interest and just about everybody knows that including Melania whom he betrayed by having an affair with 2 women including a porn actress while his wife was in a post natal condition. It is a profound mystery as to why he keeps Evangelical support given that charming conduct and Access Hollywood.
Commander in Chief means just that. He’s top dog, king of the heap. Like him or hate him, many of the posts here talk of “chain of command.” Trump is boss. Period
The military got into bed with this carnival barker, now reap what you sow.

Trumps actions show a lack of confidence and disrespect of the military system of justice, all for cheers at rallies and kudos on Fox shows and talk radio. War crimes are now officially sanctioned! If you're a draft dodger yourself, you should stay out of military affairs such as these. The military has been hugely disrespected, it's disgracful.

Gallagher is a homicidal thug who was, by his own words, identified as predisposed to the taking of life.

If there is any truth to the allegations of his fellow soldiers, he should be on trial in The Hague as a war criminal - not being “excused” by Fox News and the President.

The Navy issued a slap on the wrist when a life-sentence would have been more appropriate. He’s in the same category of human as William Calley.

Now the clueless & cowardly 5X draft dodger who knows NOTHING about the military except how to avoid serving in it thinks he knows more about running it than the admirals & generals who have devoted their lives to it. The admirals & generals are now part of the #DeepState..

We might as well have elected Alex Jones. How can ANYONE still support this clown?
Why should Gallagher settle for a job with FAUX news, when the  position of Secretary of the Navy is now vacant?

“We just want to kill as many people as possible.” - Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher. (OK, I'm a civilian but for chrissakes, I would never say this about US Navy Seals. How could one of their own could say such a thing?)

commentBody:
"At the Pentagon, a conservative bastion where Fox News is the network of choice on office televisions.."

@nytimes - can you confirm if I understand correctly that the office TVs inside the Pentagon are tuned to Fox News?!

Shame on you, 45.  You have never served your country in any capacity.  Sure, you think you're Commander-in-Chief.  Just like you think you're president.  You are those things in name only.  All you know how to lead is a failed reality TV show.  And a bankrupt casino.
Many presidents have had no military experience. Trump's problems go much deeper than that.
I wish it were possible to take an opinion poll of everyone who voted for trump in 2016, and see how many will vote for him again. I hope this incident with Gallagher will lose him a lot if support.

President Trump's catastrophic handling of his relationship of the military is excellent news. President Trump is clearly, very clearly, chomping at the bit to become President-for-life. Both him and his base would have nothing against a nice little coup if voters vote him out : for, if he loses, the Illuminati and the Secret World Communist Party will have rigged the election, correct ? And that can not stand, of course. 
But the stunning incompetence of the Commander-in-Chief as far as leadership is concerned, means, for the moment at least, that the world can rest secure in the knowledge that the US military is in no mood to keep a man with a serious bone spurs problem in the White House.
Dear Americans, please believe when I tell you that we are millions of non-Americans scared to death at the prospect of an American dictator. Especially this one.

commentBody:
Trump's military insults are piling up [CNN]

The President has insulted war heroes, prisoners of war, Gold Star families and, some critics say, tried to use the troops to score political points. He's directed 5% cuts at Veterans Affairs, which for some time he left in the control of non-veterans who happened to be members of his Mar-a-Lago club. He's neglected to visit combat zones, unlike other presidents, suggested troops' midterm election ballots not be counted, passed up Veterans Day ceremonies other leaders made time to attend and repeatedly said he knows more about military issues than generals do.

Trump redirects 3.6 Billion Dollars in active duty military funding to build his political wall.

As one reader, retired Navy replied, “where are the hero’s that have standards and the moral fiber to say
enough is enough??” .. I too am repulsed by this act,
and the act of holding critical aid, approved by a bi-partisan constituency, the Department of State and the Pentagon to a vulnerable country, Ukraine for personal political gain. We heard from career diplomats and the military alike that withholding this aid was not only undermining Ukraine but Western democracy. There were lives lost during this political errand, and the blood is on our hands.
Where are the Republicans who have standards and the moral fiber to say enough is enough? 
We must be reminded again  that the Ukrainian aid was approved by Department of State and the Pentagon and bipartisan members of Congress. It was approved because Ukraine had provided significant proof in its commitment to fighting and ending corruption, in the words of the US Government. This is not “hearsay” but factual obtainable information from Department of State and the Pentagon. Trumps willful undermining of our revered institutions and the pillars of democracy for personal gain is breaking my spirit to fight for what is right. He has truly brainwashed Republicans- truth, values and standards no longer matter, why?- Secretary of the Navy Spencer in an effort to silence Trump - to stop his vocal/Tweet/Fox News  interference in this highly sensitive case, was reduced to trying to make a side deal, and lost.
Our military will transcend whatever embarrassments Trump attempts in his pitiful effort to distract the law from bringing the American people the justice due him for his many crimes.

Headline wrong. Politicizing the military is the surest way to end our civilian democracy. Look at Latin America, Africa, even Asia. The armed forces are overwhelmingly powerful and when they get riled up no civilian regime can survive.
Obama, like Trump, was absolutely correct to oppose the 2nd Iraq war.

I’ll side with Navy Seal Gallagher and President Trump over some unelected duplicitous functionaries in the Pentagon any day.

commentBody: Gallagher stood up SEAL strong to  a guy who was shackled and sedated.  You know what.  I’ll bet Trump could have taken that guy out as well. Two GOP heroes.

" Then, without warning, according to colleagues, Chief Gallagher pulled a small hunting knife from a sheath and stabbed the sedated captive in the neck."

But was found not guilty of this purported offense.

"The highest ranks in the Navy insisted Chief Gallagher be held accountable. Mr. Trump overruled the chain of command and the secretary of the Navy was fired."

Exactly so. "Not guilty". "Insisted" in spite of "not guilty".

Trump belives in the rule of law, not that of military spite, even in the face of "not guilty". 

Gallaher was found guilty of a minor offense that is seldom if even punished so severely. 

Trump did the right thing. This is an example of draining the swamp.

commentBody:
This is one time I'm glad of the Internet's permanence and omnipresence.

I hope the record of Chief Gallagher's conduct follows him to the end of his days.

Thank you very much for publishing this article.

I have learned more from it concerning the United States, its government, and its military than ever I knew before, even though I am a veteran of ten years serving in your military.

Your armed forces have changed radically since I served your country as a commissioned officer.  The acts herein described strongly suggest that no longer would I wish to serve you, nor, given the limitations of my morality, would I be accepted to serve.
Divide and conquer--that's what Trump does. Now he has opened a rift between many within the military ranks and those in command. How does that make the US stronger?

commentBody: Thank you to Mr. Phillips and his fellow reporters for keeping this story alive. Thank God for a still free press.
This is a Navy Seals issue; let them stand up, speak out to defend their reputation.

Just want to throw out a remembrance to LT Mike Murphy, a Navy SEAL who refused to kill an unarmed civilian.  He paid dearly, as did many others, but that is the type of sacrifice we can memorialize and be proud of in this country.

@Bengals Fan- Chelsea Manning was convicted for revealing atrocities like the ones committed by Gallagher. Unlike Gallagher, no one died. I do not defend Manning, the comparison is not of two equal crimes

commentBody: All soldiers cannot obey an unlawful order. Any Commander in Chief who pardons murder especially an immoral act on the battlefield, cannot be obeyed. We tried Nazis who obeyed their Commanders and they were hung or imprisoned. All soldiers have a duty to protect country and our Constitution but our values mean nothing if the Generals and Admirals obey without a conscience. This is why War is so hard on our soldiers because they will have to deal with their conscience afterwards. Our Generals also have a duty to our soldiers to provide a moral standard through leadership and to conduct themselves as an officer. If the Generals obey this President then the soldiers can question their leadership. Czar Putin's plan is going well, divide the military between those who will follow blindly and those who follow the law. We are in dangerous times.

If you excuse, pardon or forgive, as the president did, or extol, praise or glorify a war criminal and war crime, as Fox News did, does that not make you a collaborator or accomplice or confederate to that war crime and war criminal?
And therefore at least an accessory after the fact, in not a co-conspirator even a war criminal too?
Just asking.

Thought it might be a good idea to add some truth to this paragraph “He was limp and dusty from an explosion, conscious but barely. A far cry from the fierce, masked Islamic State fighters who once seized vast swaths of Iraq and Syria, the captive was a scraggly teenager in a tank top with limbs so thin that his watch slid easily off his wrist” who would have gladly beheaded any one of our troops if he was given the opportunity.

Just another day in the upside down.

Crime is innocence, corruption justice, lies truth.

The con man is the savior. 

Trump hasn’t shot anyone on 5th Avenue yet, but he’s making it clear he’d pardon others for it.

Chief Gallagher says at the end of this article, all the SEALS respect the president. My question is, why? Also, I doubt very much that they do. The president has done nothing to earn respect. He is the laziest man on the government payroll to date.
Trump just uses troops as props. They're all props. Cops. Firefighters. Handicapped kids.

commentBody: The problem is Gallagher was aided by several other SEALs.  As horrendous as the sniper killing of a little girl, was the false confession by an 'immune to prosecution'  fellow SEAL to get this monster off the hook.  From a president with zero ethics flows his poison.  Wearing your MAGA patches with pride, SEALs?
After reading this stomach-churning report, I have only one word to describe Gallagher: Barbarian (i.e. brutal, cruel, primitive, unconscionable - qualities his commander-in-chief displays).

I saw people get 3 days bread and water for much less than what Gallagher did! I was in the navy 74-79, trumps intervention at that level is horrifying, he just pardoned war criminals how un American is that!? 
 the very thought that this cretin could be reelected is absolutely sickening.
 what is even more disturbing is the fact it could win, thanks to the electoral college you don't need to win the popular vote.

Chief Petty Officer Edward Gallagher

is going to go on Mr. Trump's campaign for 2020

and provide historic levels of joy

to Vladimir Putin.

As a former Army Captain I am deeply disturbed by the politicalization, dangerous misuse and demagoguery for TV of the chain of command by Mr. Trump, all for political points. All soldiers, but especially senior enlisted like Chief Gallagher and officers are imbued with the “no politics” principle. One reason that our nation has been safe from military coups is that we have this strict code of conduct. As professional solders we are also taught that there are rules of war.

Chief Gallagher is a rogue, undisciplined  soldier. President Trump, having not served, is an undisciplined Commander in Chief with no understanding of the proud code in which we serve.

commentBody:
Anything or anyone that Trump passes isn't safe from Trump's meddling.  This trait didn't show up during his campaign but it is problematic.  It can create chaos because just like in the Gallagher case, it can undermine channels of command.      
 
                      3 act play
Trump sees a new situation on the news that is taking over the air waves.  He decides that he can straighten everything out and get the credit for fixing the problem.  He dismisses any concerns that his staff have about him infusing himself into the situation.

Surely, this neurotic trait can lend more urgency to impeaching him.

commentBody:
How can the US push for human rights in Hong Kong and then do this?
I wish human rights would be the inner compass for all our western politicians, because only then this can be asked for by others....But I know that this is nothing more then a wish. It was always about money and power first- now it’s also about (right wing) nationalism. this will not end well...

Trump is keenly aware of public opinion.  He must feel that he has enough support in this matter from civilian voters and some in the military also that it will be a positive for him when it comes time for reelection.  It's not that public opinion supports Gallagher and what he's accused of doing.  It's that the support is for Trump's authority.  The absolute authority that autocrats around the world have long seized when coming to power is admired, often paradoxically, by the populations they lead.

His excusing a crime upon which the existing chain of command had ruled was one unfortunate piece of this.  Being unable to enforce military discipline upon a serving person for speaking for attribution is the second piece.  The precedent that is being set is that Trump will most likely treat the military as an armed version of his rally mob.  If anyone who opposes is beaten or harmed their expectation is that he will pardon them.

Citizens will begin to not trust the US military.  Within the ranks fragging will become one option to enforce discipline.  So sad.

My dad and his two brothers served during WWII. My father was Army Air Force and spent over a year in a German POW camp.  My uncles were in the first landing onto the beaches of Normandy. My uncles and 2 others were the only survivors of their regiment. I tell this because one of my uncles continued on fighting and found himself in a foxhole with a German soldier. He had to kill for survival but he never forgot that taking of a life. Never. Never.  Gallagher seems to relish his killings and that is the real issue here.

You don't have to be a chosen  very stable genius with unmatched wisdom to see that it endangers all other American service people to allow such behaviour to go unchecked. Democracy requires that the US military be trusted by people in areas they are deployed. For example Northern Syria and anywhere else. Trump is just pulling a stunt for his base.

This is NOT about no military experience!

It’s about “kingship” - the right to order “HIS military” as he sees fit.

Yes, there’s grievance there, but this is mostly about power: exerting his - because he can - and contempt for the structure, the honor, the System he could never measure up to.

But, he can order it, like lining up his toy soldiers, and he can break it... so he will.

Remember: NOTHING MATTERS BUT TRUMP!

This is his way of reminding them of that: of his ability to demonstrate his power over the powerful.

God help us!

Interestingly, this may be more damaging for Trump than his criminal shakedown of Ukraine.  It is such an unsavory move and speaks more to his character than the volumes of the Mueller report and hours of impeachment hearings.  Trump's brand of corruption is silent like heart disease and is now seeping into our most honored traditions.  Republicans think this is the same as any of his other inane acts, but it isn't.  They will not bother defending this, because "it is just Trump, being Trump".   And in 2020, they will not be able to discern his defeat ahead of time.
Trump is commander in chief and the Pentagon is duty bound to follow his lawful (emphasis on "lawful") orders. It's just the way it is. Thou does not need to like it, thou just needs to do it.

commentBody:
This is “a lesson in how [a salesman] presides over the armed forces.”

Republicans apparently will tolerate anything for the sake of tribe. That’s no tired sarcasm anymore. The reality a severe threat to our form of government. (more words, words, words...)

And apparently there’s nothing that will cause the Cabinet to invoke the 25th Amendment. THAT’s a severe threat to our form of government.

We have a salesman in the Oval Office who has no PRESIDENTIAL interest. Playing proprietary CEO is itself an abuse of the office—not merely an abuse of “power.” It’s a matter of the dignity and integrity of the American form of government.

Though we’re not on the way to the situation of Germany in the 1930s, can we now better understand why citizens just hand wring, try to go on with their lives, but wake up to catastrophe that everyone thought was never possible? 

Trump is a walking danger to American security in the world. He's causing loss to American credibility that will take years to recover.

Putin is having a ball.
If we have to deploy the same Americans to a war zone 8 times (as with Gallagher) we definitely need to reinstate the draft.
